t: And all the assembly lifted up their voice, and cried with a loud voice unto the Lord God.
Then said Ozias unto them, Brethren, be of good courage, let us yet endure five days, in the which space the Lord our God may look upon us; for he will not forsake us utterly.
And if these days pass, and there come no help unto us, I will do according to your words.

And now dismiss the people unto their several charges: and they went their way to the walls and towers of their city, and the women and children they sent home also: and they were in great heaviness in the city.

Now at that time Judith heard thereof, which was the daughter of Merari, the son of Ox, the son of Joseph, the son of Oziel, the son of Elkiah, the son of Ananias, the son of Gideon, the son of Raphaim, the son of Ahitub, the son of Eliab, the son of Nathanael, the son of Samael, the son of Salasadai, the son of Israel.
And Manasses was her husband, of her tribe and kindred, who died in the barley harvest.

For as he stood overseeing them that bound sheaves in the field, the heat came upon his head, and he fell sick, and died in Bethulia his own city, and they buried him with his fathers in the field between Dothaim and Balamon.
So Judith was a widow now three years and four months.
And she made her a tent upon the top of her house, and put on sackcloth upon her loins, and ware her widow's apparel.

And she fasted all the days of her widowhood, save the eves of the sabbaths, and the sabbaths themselves, and the eves of the new moons, and the new moons themselves, and the feasts and solemn days of the house of Israel.

She was also of a goodly countenance, and very beautiful to behold: and her husband Manasses had left her gold, and silver, and menservants, and maidservants, and cattle, and lands; and she remained upon them.
And there was no man that gave her an ill word; for she feared God greatly.

Now when she heard the evil words of the people against the governor, that they fainted for lack of water; for Judith had heard all the words that Ozias had spoken unto them, and that he had sworn to deliver the city unto the Assyrians after five days.
Then she sent her waitingwoman, that had the oversight of all things that she had, to call Ozias and Chabris and Charmis, the ancients of the city.

And they came unto her, and she said unto them, Hear me now, O ye governors of the inhabitants of Bethulia: for your words that ye have spoken before the people this day are not right, touching this oath which ye made and pronounced between God and you, and have promised to deliver the city to our enemies, unless within these five days the Lord do send you help.
And now who are ye that have tempted God this day, and stand instead of God among the children of men?
And now try the Lord Almighty, but ye shall never know any thing.

For ye cannot find out the depth of the heart of man, neither can ye perceive the things that he thinketh: then how can ye search out God, that hath made all these things, and know his mind, or comprehend his purpose? nay, my brethren, provoke not the Lord our God.
For if he will not help us within these five days, he hath power to defend us when he will, even every day, or to destroy us before our enemies.
Do not bind the counsels of the Lord our God: for God is not as man, that he may be threatened; neither is he as the son of man, that he may be wavering.
Therefore let us wait for salvation of him, and call upon him to help us, and he will hear our voice, if it please him.
For there arose none in our age, neither is there any now in our days, neither tribe, nor family, nor people, nor city among us, which worship gods made with hands, as hath been aforetime.
For the which cause our fathers were given to the sword, and for a spoil, and had a great fall before our enemies.
But we know none other god, therefore we trust that he will not despise us, nor forsake our nation.
For if we be taken so, all Judea shall lie waste, and our sanctuary shall be spoiled; and he will require the profanation thereof at our mouth.

And the slaughter of our brethren, and the captivity of the country, and the desolation of our inheritance, will he turn upon our heads among the Gentiles, wheresoever we shall be in bondage; and we shall be an offence and a reproach to all them that possess us.
For our servitude shall not be directed to favour: but the Lord our God shall turn it to dishonour.
Now therefore, O brethren, let us shew an example to our brethren, because their hearts depend upon us, and the sanctuary, and the house, and the altar, rest upon us.
Moreover let us give thanks to the Lord our God, which trieth us, even as he did our fathers.
Remember what he did with Abraham, and how he tried Isaac, and what happened to Jacob in Mesopotamia of Syria, when he kept the sheep of Laban his mother's brother.
For he hath not tried us for ever, to take vengeance; but for admonition, that his heart might be turned unto him, he scourgeth them that come near unto him.
Then said Ozias unto her, All that thou hast spoken is true, and there is nothing that any man can gainsay.
For we know that thy heart is good, and that thou fearest God, and that there is no nation nor city, nor people, that knoweth thee, because thy wisdom is so great.
But the people are sore athirst, and compelled us to do unto them as we have spoken, and to bind ourselves with an oath, which we will not break.
Therefore now pray thou for us, because thou art a godly woman, and the Lord will send us rain to fill our cisterns, and we shall faint no more.
Then said Judith unto them, Hear me, and I will do a thing, which shall go throughout all generations to the children of our nation.

Ye shall stand this night in the gate, and I will go forth with my waitingwoman: and within the days that ye have promised to deliver the city unto our enemies the Lord will visit Israel by mine hand.
But enquire not ye of mine act: for I will not declare it unto you, till the things be finished that I do.
Then said Ozias and the princes unto her, Go in peace, and the Lord God be before thee, that thou mayest take vengeance of our enemies.
So they returned from the tent, and went unto their places.
Then Judith fell upon her face, and put ashes upon her head, and uncovered the sackcloth wherewith she was clothed, and cried with a loud voice unto the Lord, and said,

O Lord God of my father Simeon, to whom thou gavest a sword to take vengeance of the strangers, who loosened the girdle of a maid to defile her, and discovered her thigh to her shame, and polluted her virginity to her reproach; for thou saidst, It shall not be so; and yet they did so:
wherefore thou gavest their rulers to be slain, so that they dyed the bed in blood, being deceived, and smotest the servants with their lords, and the lords with their servants;

and gavest their wives for a prey, and their daughters to be captives, and all their spoils to be divided among thy dear children; which were moved with thy zeal, and abhorred the pollution of their blood, and called upon thee for aid: O God, O my God, hear me also a widow.
For thou hast wrought not only those things, but also the things which fell out before, and which ensued after; thou hast thought upon the things which are now, and which are to come.
Yea, what things soever thou willest, do shall come to pass; and thy purposes from the beginning shall stand at thy commandment.
For thy power is great, and thy name is honourable for ever. O Lord, shew thy mercy upon us: O Lord God, look upon us, and behold.

For the heathen are gathered together against us to destroy us: they are prepared to defile thy sanctuary, and to lay waste the place where thy glorious name dwelleth, and to cast down with sword the horn of thy altar.
Behold their pride, and send thy wrath upon their heads: give unto me, which am a widow, the power to do the thing which I have purposed.
O Lord God of my inheritance, give me a deceitful tongue, and smite the servant with the prince, and the prince with the servant: break down their stateliness by the hand of a woman.

For thy power standeth not in multitude, nor thy might in strong men: for thou art a God of the afflicted, an helper of the oppressed, an upholder of the weak, a protector of the forlorn, a saviour of them that are without hope.
I pray thee, I pray thee, O God of my father, and God of the inheritance of Israel, Lord of the heavens and earth, Creator of the waters, King of every creature, hear thou my prayer:

and make my speech and deceit to be their wound and stripe, who have purposed cruel things against thy covenant, and thy holy house, and against the top of Sion, and against the house of the possession of thy children.
And make every nation and tribe to acknowledge that thou art the God of all power and might, and that there is none other that protecteth the people of Israel but thou.
Now it was long after that she had left off weeping.
And when she had ended her prayer, she rose up from the place where she lay prostrate before the Lord.
Then she called her waitingwoman, and went down into the house in the which she abode in the sabbath days, and in her festival days.

And she pulled off the sackcloth which she had on, and put off the garments of her widowhood, and washed her body all over with water, and anointed herself with precious ointment, and braided the hair of her head, and put on a tire upon it, and put on her garments of gladness, wherewith she was clad during the life of Manasses her husband.

And she took sandals upon her feet, and put about her her bracelets, and her chains, and her rings, and her earrings, and all her ornaments, and decked herself bravely, to allure the eyes of all men that should see her.

Then she gave her waitingwoman a bottle of wine, and a cruse of oil, and filled a bag with parched barley, and cakes of figs, and fine bread; so she folded all these things together, and laid them upon her.
Thus they went forth toward the gate of the city of Bethulia, and found standing there Ozias, and the ancients of the city.
And when they saw her, that her countenance was altered, and her apparel was changed, they wondered at her beauty very greatly, and said unto her,

The God, the God of our fathers give thee favour, and accomplish all thy counsel to the glory of the children of Israel, and to the exaltation of Jerusalem. Then said she unto them, Command the gates of the city to be opened unto me, that I may go forth to accomplish the things whereof ye have spoken with me. So they commanded the young men that they should open unto her, as she had said.

And when they had done so, Judith went out, she, and her waitingwoman with her; and the men of the city looked after her, until she was gone down the mountain, and till she had passed the valley, and could see her no more.
Thus they went straight forth in the valley: and the first watch of the Assyrians met her.

And they took her, and asked her, Of what people art thou? and whence comest thou? and whither goest thou? And she said, I am a woman of the Hebrews, therefore am I fled from them: for they shall be given you to be consumed.
And I am coming before Holofernes the chief captain of your army, to declare things that shall save all the region, from the uttermost part of the hills.
When the men heard her words, and beheld her countenance, they were greatly astonished at her beauty.

And they said unto her, Thou hast saved thy life, in that thou hast hasted to come down to the presence of our lord: now therefore come thou to his tent, and some of us shall conduct thee, until we have delivered thee to his hand.
And when thou standest before him, thou shalt not be afraid in thine heart, but shew unto him according to thy knowledge, and he will entreat thee well.
Then they chose out of them an hundred men to accompany her and her maid; and they brought her to the tent of Holofernes.

Then was there a running to and fro throughout the camp: for her coming was noised among the tents. They came about her on every side, and she was without forth the tent of Holofernes, till they told him of her.

And they wondered at her beauty, and admired her greatly; so that they said one to another, Who would despise this people, that have women among them of such stature? surely it is not good that one man of them be left, who being let go might deceive the whole earth.
And they that lay near Holofernes went out, and all his servants, and they brought her into the tent.
Now Holofernes rested upon his bed under a canopy, which was woven with purple, and gold, and emeralds, and precious stones.
So they shewed him of her; and he came forth before his tent, with silver lamps going before him.
And when Judith was come before him and his servants, they all marvelled at the beauty of her countenance; and she fell down upon her face, and did reverence unto him: and his servants took her up.
Then said Holofernes unto her, Woman, be of good comfort, fear not in thine heart: for I never hurt any that was willing to serve Nabuchodonosor, the king of all the earth.
Now therefore, if thy people that dwelleth in the mountains had not set light by me, I would not have lifted up my spear against them: but they have done these things to themselves.
And now tell me wherefore thou art fled from them, and art come unto us: for thou art come to be safe; be of good courage, thou shalt live this night, and hereafter:
None shall do thee harm, go forth! But thou shalt be entreated well, as is the manner with the servants of my lord King Nebuchadnezzar.
And Judith said: "Deign to receive favorably the words of thy handmaid, and let thy servant speak before thee. This night I shall utter no falsehood before my Lord.
Only follow the counsel of thy handmaid, and God shall bring thy matter to good effect, my Lord shall not fail in his enterprises.

Live Nebuchadnezzar, king of all the earth, who hath sent thee to set every living soul in the right path, and live his power! For, by thee, not only do men serve him, but by the effect of thy strength, the wild beasts themselves, the flocks, and the birds of the sky shall live for Nebuchadnezzar and for all his house!`"

We have, in very truth, heard tell of thy talent and the resources of thy mind. It is a thing known throughout all the earth that, in all the empire, thou art singularly capable, rich in experience, and astonishing in the conduct of war.
And then, we know the discourse spoken by Achior in thy council. The people of Bethulia, having spared him, have communicated unto them all that he had said unto thee.

Now, master and lord, neglect not his words, but keep them present in thy mind, for they are true. Verily, our race shall not be chastised, the sword shall avail naught against her sons unless they sin against their God.

Now, even now, lest my Lord know neither rebuff nor failure, death shall descend upon their heads. For sin hath seized them, that sin by which they stir the wrath of their God each time they give themselves over to disorder.

Since victuals are lacking unto them and water is scarce, they have resolved to fall back upon their flocks and have decided to take for themselves all that, by His laws, God hath forbidden them to eat.

Even unto the first fruits of the wheat, to the tithes of the wine and the oil - things consecrated and reserved by them unto the priests who, in Jerusalem, stand before the face of our God - they have decided to consume. Yet none of the people hath the right to touch them, even with their hand.
Yea more, they have sent unto Jerusalem, where all the people do likewise, men charged to bring them from the Council of the elders the permission necessary.
Behold then what shall come to pass: as soon as the permission is come and they have made use of it, on that very day shall they be delivered unto thee for their ruin.
When I, thy servant, had learned all these things, I fled from among them. God hath sent me to achieve with thee enterprises at which the whole earth shall be astonished when they are learned.

For thy handmaid is a pious woman. Night and day she honors the God of heaven. Therefore I propose to remain near thee, my Lord. I, thy servant, shall go forth by night into the ravine and there pray to God that He make known unto me when they have consumed their sin.
I shall then return to inform thee that thou mayest go forth with all thine army, and none among them shall be able to resist thee.

I shall lead thee through all Judea until thou comest before Jerusalem. I shall seat thee in the midst of the city. Then thou shalt lead them as sheep without a shepherd, and there shall not be even a dog to bark before thee. Of all this have I had a presentiment, it hath been announced unto me, and I have been sent to reveal it unto thee.
The words of this woman pleased Holofernes and all his aides-de-camp. Astonished by her wisdom, they cried out:
"From one end of the world to the other there is no woman like her, so beautiful and so well-spoken!
And Holofernes said unto her: "God hath done well to send thee before the people! In our hands shall be the power, and unto those who have despised my lord, ruin.

As for thee, thou art as fair as thou art skilled in thy speech. If thou doest as thou hast said, thy God shall be my God, and thou shalt dwell in the palace of King Nebuchadnezzar and thou shalt be renowned throughout all the earth!
